Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Visualization Conference

Title: Legibility enhancement for information visualisation
Abstract: Navigation in computer generated information spaces may be difficult, resulting in users getting 'lost in hyperspace.' This work aims to build on research from the area of city planning to try to solve this problem. We will introduce the concepts of legibility and cognitive maps and the five features of urban landscape with which they are associated. Following this will be descriptions of techniques and algorithms which we have developed to allow these features to be introduced to three dimensional spaces for information visualisation. Next we will describe a specific application of these techniques in the visualisation of the World Wide Web and conclude with a look at future development of the system.
Publisher: IEEE, Los Alamitos, CA, United States
Conference name: Proceedings of the 1995 6th Annual IEEE Conference on Visualization
Authors: Ingram Rob, Benford Steve
Authors with affiliations: Ingram, Rob, Univ of Nottingham, Nottingham, United Kingdom; Benford, Steve, Univ of Nottingham, Nottingham, United Kingdom
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Visualization Conference

Title: Proceedings of the 1995 6th Annual IEEE Conference on Visualization
Abstract: The proceedings contains 61 papers. Topics discussed include volume rendering, ray tracing, splatting, visualization in molecular interfaces and biology, databases, sonification and color, isosurfaces, data compression, information visualization, vector and tensor, exploratory visualization, icons and objects, flow visualization, case studies in mathematics and philosophy, design and manufacturing, astrophysics, fluid dynamics, fish, marine mammals and their environment.
Publisher: IEEE, Los Alamitos, CA, United States
Conference name: Proceedings of the 1995 6th Annual IEEE Conference on Visualization
Authors: [No author name available]
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Visualization Conference

Title: Pictorial statistics - visualization of high-dimensional statistical distributions
Abstract: A general framework for visualization of statistical properties of high-dimensional pattern samples and the related computational steps are introduced. These procedures are exemplified on applications in anthropometrical research (shape information in faces) but can be easily generalized to various other morphometrical questions and data sets with pattern structure, e.g., data stemming from sensor arrays. Presently, the visualization techniques illustrated concentrate on (higher) moments of first order. It is suggested, how moments of second order can be visualized by animations and how this approach can be used in the context of comparative visualization.
Publisher: IEEE, Los Alamitos, CA, United States
Conference name: Proceedings of the 1995 6th Annual IEEE Conference on Visualization
Authors: Mueller Andreas A.
Authors with affiliations: Mueller, Andreas A., Univ of Goettingen, Goettingen, Germany
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Visualization Conference

Title: Illustrated analysis of sonification for scientific visualisation
Abstract: This paper presents an analysis of progress in the use of sound as a tool in support of visualisation and gives an insight into its development and future needs. Special emphasis is given to the use of sound in Scientific and Engineering Applications. A system developed to support surface data presentation and interaction by using sound is presented and discussed.
Publisher: IEEE, Los Alamitos, CA, United States
Conference name: Proceedings of the 1995 6th Annual IEEE Conference on Visualization
Authors: Minghim R., Forrest A.R.
Authors with affiliations: Minghim, R., Univ of East Anglia, Norwich, United Kingdom; Forrest, A.R., Univ of East Anglia, Norwich, United Kingdom
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Visualization Conference

Title: Visualizing the internet: putting the user in the driver's seat
Abstract: Information is dispersed over many Internet resources and quite frequently, users feel lost, confused, and overwhelmed. The panel and the audience will discuss how advances in interactive computer graphics and visualization software and hardware could make the information distributed over the Internet more intuitively searchable, accessible, and easier to use by people from all walks of life and interests. This will enable the user to make full use of the Internet's information universe from our computers.
Conference name: Proceedings of the 1995 6th Annual IEEE Conference on Visualization
Authors: Gershon Nahum, Eick Stephen G., Foley James, Hardin Joseph, Kappe Frank, Ruh William A.
Authors with affiliations: Gershon, Nahum, AT&T Bell Lab, United States; Eick, Stephen G., AT&T Bell Lab, United States; Foley, James, AT&T Bell Lab, United States; Hardin, Joseph, AT&T Bell Lab, United States; Kappe, Frank, AT&T Bell Lab, United States; Ruh, William A., AT&T Bell Lab, United States
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Visualization Conference

Title: Visualizing multidimensional (multivariate) data and relations - perception vs geometry
Abstract: Visualization methodologies that are perceptually satisfying, intuitive, and that preserve multidimensional information are considered. The approach used focused on the foundations, particularly the concepts as against the tools. Starting with a review of the field, visualization is studied as a collection of transformations from 'problem domains' to a perceptual domain, usually visual. This general notion is given specific explanations. A variety rather than a single transformation is examined, since various applications may require specialized notions of visualization. Visualization is seen no longer simply as another application but includes databases, real-time interaction, networking, supercomputing, multimedia, visual programming, systems theory, and human perception.
Conference name: Proceedings of the 1995 6th Annual IEEE Conference on Visualization
Authors: Grinstein Georges, Buja Andreas, Asimov Daniel, Inselberg Alfred
Authors with affiliations: Grinstein, Georges, Univ of Mass.-Lowell, United States; Buja, Andreas, Univ of Mass.-Lowell, United States; Asimov, Daniel, Univ of Mass.-Lowell, United States; Inselberg, Alfred, Univ of Mass.-Lowell, United States
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Visualization Conference

Title: Recursive pattern: a technique for visualizing very large amounts of data
Abstract: An important goal of visualization technology is to support the exploration and analysis of very large amounts of data. In this paper, we propose a new visualization technique called 'recursive pattern' which has been developed for visualizing large amounts of multidimensional data. The technique is based on a generic recursive scheme which generalizes a wide range of pixel-oriented arrangements for displaying large data sets. By instantiating the technique with adequate data- and application-dependent parameters, the user may largely influence the structure of the resulting visualizations. Since the technique uses one pixel for presenting each data value, the amount of data which can be displayed is only limited by the resolution of current display technology and by the limitations of human perceptibility. Beside describing the basic idea of the 'recursive pattern' technique, we provide several examples of useful parameter settings for the various recursion levels. We further show that our 'recursive pattern' technique is particularly advantageous for the large class of data sets which have a natural order according to one dimension (e.g. time series data). We demonstrate the usefulness of our technique by using a stock market application.
Publisher: IEEE, Los Alamitos, CA, United States
Conference name: Proceedings of the 1995 6th Annual IEEE Conference on Visualization
Authors: Keim Daniel A., Kriegel Hans-Peter, Ankerst Mihael
Authors with affiliations: Keim, Daniel A., Univ of Munich, Munich, Germany; Kriegel, Hans-Peter, Univ of Munich, Munich, Germany; Ankerst, Mihael, Univ of Munich, Munich, Germany
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Visualization Conference

Title: Propositional n-traces: visualizing a problem in philosophical logic
Abstract: As part of an inter-disciplinary effort, we are visually exploring a current problem in philosophical logic related to information processing. Given a set of inconsistent sentences or inputs, a processor cannot unambiguously infer any specific consequence. Traces represent subsets of possible consequences which can be inferred classically from partitions of the set of inputs. We are interested in the relationship between a given set of Boolean inputs and its respective trace(s). We have developed a visualization paradigm which allows us to view and explore this relationship effectively.
Publisher: IEEE, Los Alamitos, CA, United States
Conference name: Proceedings of the 1995 6th Annual IEEE Conference on Visualization
Authors: Prevost Nathalie, Jorgenson Loki, Jennings R.E., Fracchia F.David
Authors with affiliations: Prevost, Nathalie, Simon Fraser Univ, Burnaby, Canada; Jorgenson, Loki, Simon Fraser Univ, Burnaby, Canada; Jennings, R.E., Simon Fraser Univ, Burnaby, Canada; Fracchia, F.David, Simon Fraser Univ, Burnaby, Canada
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Visualization Conference

Title: Fast algorithms for visualizing fluid motion in steady flow on unstructured grids
Abstract: The plotting of streamlines is an effective way of visualizing fluid motion in steady flows. Additional information about the flowfield, such as local rotation and expansion, can be shown by drawing in the form of a ribbon or tube. In this paper, we present efficient algorithms for the construction of streamlines, stream-ribbons and streamtubes on unstructured grids. A specialized version of the Runge-Kutta method has been developed to speed up the integration of particle paths. We have also derived close-form solutions for calculating angular rotation rate and radius to construct streamribbons and streamtubes, respectively. According to our analysis and test results, these formulations are two to four times better in performance than previous numerical methods. As a large number of traces are calculated, the improved performance could be significant.
Publisher: IEEE, Los Alamitos, CA, United States
Conference name: Proceedings of the 1995 6th Annual IEEE Conference on Visualization
Authors: Ueng S.K., Sikorski K., Ma Kwan-Liu
Authors with affiliations: Ueng, S.K., Univ of Utah, Salt Lake City, United States; Sikorski, K., Univ of Utah, Salt Lake City, United States; Ma, Kwan-Liu, Univ of Utah, Salt Lake City, United States
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Visualization Conference

Title: Fast normal estimation using surface characteristics
Abstract: To visualize the volume data acquired from computation or sampling, it is necessary to estimate normals at the points corresponding to object surfaces. Volume data does not holds the geometric information for the surface comprising points, so it is necessary to calculate normals using local information at each point. The existing normal estimation methods have some problems of estimating incorrect normals at discontinuous, aliased or noisy points. Yagel et al solved some of these problems using their context-sensitive method. However this method requires too much processing time and it loses some information on detailed parts of the object surfaces. This paper proposes the surface-characteristic-sensitive normal estimation method which applies different operators according to characteristics of each surface for the normal calculation. This method has the same advantages of the context-sensitive method, and also some other advantages such as the less processing time and the reduction of the information loss on detailed parts.
Publisher: IEEE, Los Alamitos, CA, United States
Conference name: Proceedings of the 1995 6th Annual IEEE Conference on Visualization
Authors: Shin Byeong Seok, Shin Yeong Gil
Authors with affiliations: Shin, Byeong Seok, Seoul Natl Univ, Seoul, South Korea; Shin, Yeong Gil, Seoul Natl Univ, Seoul, South Korea
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Visualization Conference

Title: Supporting heterogeneous data import for data visualization
Abstract: Effective data visualization requires the combination of datasets from a variety of sources and in a variety of data formats. Unfortunately, visualization software systems typically support only a rudimentary tabular data import facility, forcing the system user to construct elaborate ad hoc data import mechanisms. We describe the construction of a `front-end' conversion system designed to allow the simple import of a wide range of public, private, and locally defined data formats of particular interest in natural resource visualization applications.
Publisher: ACM, New York, NY, United States
Conference name: Proceedings of the 1995 ACM Symposium on Applied Computing
Authors: Ford R., Thompson R., Thompson D.
Authors with affiliations: Ford, R., Univ of Montana, Missoula, United States; Thompson, R., Univ of Montana, Missoula, United States; Thompson, D., Univ of Montana, Missoula, United States
Source title: Proceedings of the ACM Symposium on Applied Computing

Title: Ray tracing as a tool for visualization of pathogen spread in natural forest stands
Abstract: This paper describes the application of ray tracing, rendering, and morphing technology to the study and analysis of the spread of dwarf mistletoe. The practical problems involved in examining the spread and speed of such a slow pathogen, with such serious economic consequences, is illustrated. The utility of applying this standard graphics technology to similar forest diseases of this type is also established. Practical examples of this technology transfer are given on a database of 6000 trees with information collected over 15 years.
Publisher: ACM, New York, NY, United States
Conference name: Proceedings of the 1995 ACM Symposium on Applied Computing
Authors: Hoskins J.A., Hoskins W.D.
